thread.title: The Verdict: What happens if Karl Stefanovic's ticket to prime time is a bust?
thread.title_full: The Verdict: What happens if Karl Stefanovic's ticket to prime time is a bust?

author: Neil McMahon
title: The Verdict: What happens if Karl Stefanovic's ticket to prime time is a bust?
text:
Click to play video Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
Video will begin in 5 seconds.
Don't play Play now More video Recommended Replay video Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
Karl Stefanovic delivers The Verdict The Nine host had his work cut out for him in his first foray into prime time television.
PT1M9S http://www.canberratimes.com.au/action/externalEmbeddedPlayer?id=d-44674 620 349 October 9, 2015 - 11:08AM Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings The Verdict was a stinking mess and no match for Q&A ANALYSIS 
The verdict is in on Channel Nine's The Verdict - and in the aftermath of a critical panning, a social-media pasting and a ratings thumping all eyes will be on what this all-round balls-up means for the ever-rising star of network lynchpin Karl Stefanovic.
Karl Stefanovic will serve as 'chair' of Nine's new talk show. 
In the only battleground that really counts - for the hearts and mind of viewers - the numbers for Thursday night's ramshackle debut of The Verdict will be giving Nine bosses the yips today.
Advertisement A program billed as Nine's loosey-goosey answer to the ABC's Q&A drew a capital city audience of just 522,000 viewers, languishing in 19th place for the night and beaten by timeslot rivals Highway Patrol (a repeat of a car-crash clip-show on Seven, which nudged 700,000) and Ten's Gogglebox on 559,000.
Those are very ordinary numbers in the 8.30pm timeslot for a heavily promoted new program months in the planning, fronted by the network's biggest star - and coming off a healthy lead-in audience from top-ten rated T he Block .
Opening night: The Verdict Photo: Channel Nine 
And they cast a cloud - a small one, but a cloud nonetheless - over what has long been taken for granted within the industry: that Stefanovic will inevitably parlay his star stature and network influence into a permanent, flagship, night-time role, leaving behind the decade-long grind of pre-dawn starts and bitter ratings battles of breakfast television.
Not much has gone badly wrong for Stefanovic over the years - and even when it has (think drunk on air, post-Logies 2009) he's had the lucky-charm ability to come through smiling and even to embed the mistake as a part of his powerful television "brand": Kid Karl, Nine's all-round big-match player who's also a bit of a goofball lad.
Winners are, indeed, grinners, and he's mostly been a winner - the obvious heir to the Nine tradition of genial, versatile, multi-talented, big-name, one-name superstars that stretches back through Eddie and Ray to the newsreading Brians to the original princes of the Packer palace, Bert and Graham.
Foreign Minister Julie Bishop with Today host Karl Stefanovic. 
Karl, we have learned over the years, can do just about anything. And while many find his blokey schtick annoying, it's foolish to deny his talents - from serious journalistic chops that make him a stand-out when big stories break to that other, more ephemeral quality that finds him completely at home when asked - to borrow from Paul Keating - to throw the switch to vaudeville. He's Ray Martin with added clown.
But quite how  those varied talents are best utilised in a permanent prime-time role still remains uncertain - especially after Thursday night, when what had seemed on paper a natural fit for Stefanovic proved to be anything but.
Of course, it is unfair to lump the host with all or even most of the blame - he found himself ringmaster of an incoherent production burdened by too many guests, an grabbag of mismatched segments and a reliance on rowdy conflict that turned many viewers off.
Selfie time ... Karl Stefanovic kisses Chrissie Swan as she takes a selfie at the Logie Awards in May. Photo: Getty Images 
The concept may simply be wrong for Nine; it may also be wrong for Stefanovic as currently designed. Or perhaps, with some major re-thinking, it can find its feet and thrive.
Whatever happens, that long-time staple TV story - "What's next for Karl?" - is going to run for a little while yet.
